title: Manipulate hacker profile and private program hacktivity to expose your name as researchers who is actively submitting reports with resolve status

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi Team,

**Summary:**

First of all, the issue that i have found have multiple steps, so please make sure to follow the steps accordingly.

I was able to put my hacker name on private program hacktivity profile showing that i have report that was resolved, this will also reflect to my hacker profile.

## Requirements:

- The program should have a security forwarding feature
- The hacker/researcher will use the hackerone publishing feature

For PoC purposes, I have tested it in [███████](https://hackerone.com/███████) private program because they have `security@` email forwarding: `hackerone@█████████.com`.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Assume that you are not invited to [███████](https://hackerone.com/██████████) private program private program, first step, use the publish feature, go here: https://hackerone.com/hacktivity/publish
2. Submit a publish report, put ████████ (███████) in Program (see below), put any test details and hit `Publish Vulnerability`.
████
3. Now the vulnerability is under `Pending review` by a moderator
4. Send a test mail to `hackerone@████.com` to get an invitation to submit a report, accept the invitation and you will become a participant of the said private program.
5. After that you will observed after how many hours, it will show on the private program hacktivity page your publish report will show as `resolved` ███████ and displayed on their hacktivity timeline, this will also show on your hacker profile time line ███. 

## Additional PoC below:

████

The report number of that publish report is https://hackerone.com/reports/652941 , __please note that this test publish report is still under pending review by the moderator.

## Impact

Hacker can manipulate the private program hacktivity page to show his/her hackerone name to look like there is so many report that was submitted and resolved.

This will also manipulate the hacker profile to show that he/she have many report that was submitted and resolved to a particular private program.

Audience for that hacker will be tricked.

Let me know if you need additional information.

Regards
Japz
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi Team,

Summary:

First of all, the issue that i have found have multiple steps, so please make sure to follow the steps accordingly.

I was able to put my hacker name on private program hacktivity profile showing that i have report that was resolved, this will also reflect to my hacker profile.

Requirements:

  • The program should have a security forwarding feature
  • The hacker/researcher will use the hackerone publishing feature

For PoC purposes, I have tested it in ███████ private program because they have security@ email forwarding: hackerone@█████████.com.

Steps To Reproduce

  1. Assume that you are not invited to ███████ private program private program, first step, use the publish feature, go here: https://hackerone.com/hacktivity/publish
  2. Submit a publish report, put ████████ (███████) in Program (see below), put any test details and hit Publish Vulnerability. ████
  3. Now the vulnerability is under Pending review by a moderator
  4. Send a test mail to hackerone@████.com to get an invitation to submit a report, accept the invitation and you will become a participant of the said private program.
  5. After that you will observed after how many hours, it will show on the private program hacktivity page your publish report will show as resolved ███████ and displayed on their hacktivity timeline, this will also show on your hacker profile time line ███.

Additional PoC below:

████

The report number of that publish report is https://hackerone.com/reports/652941 , __please note that this test publish report is still under pending review by the moderator.

Impact

Hacker can manipulate the private program hacktivity page to show his/her hackerone name to look like there is so many report that was submitted and resolved.

This will also manipulate the hacker profile to show that he/she have many report that was submitted and resolved to a particular private program.

Audience for that hacker will be tricked.

Let me know if you need additional information.

Regards
Japz

activities.message:
Another thing is, the [██████████](https://hackerone.com/████) submit report button is currently disabled, means they are taking a break and not accepting submissions, __But__ still i can manipulate their hacktivity timeline to show/flood it with my name showing i have a resolved reports despite they are taking a break and not accepting submissions. It is not good for your customers.

To confirm that i can continuously exploited, i created another publish reports, after 40 mins it shows again on their hacktivity that i have a report that was resolved, it is also showing on my hacker profile. (see below PoC)

████████

Also, this will appear on HackerOne Hacktivity timeline (see below image)

███████

Please note that after this, i will stop doing another PoC to avoid flooding their timeline with my name, unless you will give me permission to do so (if needed another PoC).

Cheers
Japz

It is not good for your customers.

To confirm that i can continuously exploited, i created another publish reports, after 40 mins it shows again on their hacktivity that i have a report that was resolved, it is also showing on my hacker profile. (see below PoC)

████████

Also, this will appear on HackerOne Hacktivity timeline (see below image)

███████

Please note that after this, i will stop doing another PoC to avoid flooding their timeline with my name, unless you will give me permission to do so (if needed another PoC).

Cheers
Japz

activities.message:
Hi @chessmast3r ,

Thanks for the response.

Being able to manipulate the private programs hacktivity already shows an impact, the hacker profile and hackerone hacktivity is also affected.

If someone can show their name as active hacker which looks like having too many resolved reports is indeed a security issue despite they don't have REAL submitted resolved report.

Please also note that even the program submission button was disabled (meaning to say they are taking a break), the attacker can still populate their hacktivity timeline with names showing resolved reports.

>I'm going to discuss this internally for the better understanding. 

Sounds good, please let me know if you guys having trouble understanding my report.

Regards
Japz

Please also note that even the program submission button was disabled (meaning to say they are taking a break), the attacker can still populate their hacktivity timeline with names showing resolved reports.

I'm going to discuss this internally for the better understanding.

Sounds good, please let me know if you guys having trouble understanding my report.

Regards
Japz

activities.message:
Hi @japz -

Thanks for the report! You brought to our attention that it's not obvious - and in certain cases not possible - to distinguish a hacker-published report from a report submitted on H1 on Hacktivity entry. 
- For a disclosed report, you can distinguish them by "Disclosed a day ago" vs. "Published a day ago" in the timestamp;
- For a non-disclosed report, like those you pointed out in private programs, there isn't a visual difference. 

Our engineering team has worked out a solution to visually differentiate hacker published reports on Hacktivity by adding an icon. However, the security implication here is very minimal, given that:
- It doesn't happen often (only to private programs, and has to be approved by H1 staff);
- It doesn't affect the hacker's metrics, e.g. reputation, signal, etc.

We'll get the UX fix out soon, and again, thanks for your report. 

-Pei
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @japz -

Thanks for the report! You brought to our attention that it's not obvious - and in certain cases not possible - to distinguish a hacker-published report from a report submitted on H1 on Hacktivity entry.

  • For a disclosed report, you can distinguish them by "Disclosed a day ago" vs. "Published a day ago" in the timestamp;
  • For a non-disclosed report, like those you pointed out in private programs, there isn't a visual difference.

Our engineering team has worked out a solution to visually differentiate hacker published reports on Hacktivity by adding an icon. However, the security implication here is very minimal, given that:

  • It doesn't happen often (only to private programs, and has to be approved by H1 staff);
  • It doesn't affect the hacker's metrics, e.g. reputation, signal, etc.

We'll get the UX fix out soon, and again, thanks for your report.

-Pei

activities.message:
Hi @pei ,

I disagree, please read below. It seems that you don't understand it well because you said;

>It doesn't happen often (only to private programs, and has to be approved by H1 staff);

__WRONG__ , My test publish reports was __NOT YET APPROVE__, you can check it by going to this test publish report in my PoC.

https://hackerone.com/reports/652941
https://hackerone.com/reports/654130

You will see that the status is still __PENDING REVIEW__.

>It doesn't affect the hacker's metrics, e.g. reputation, signal, etc.

It does not affect the metrics, __BUT__ it affects the hacker hacktivity! , It shows in my hacktivity and there is UPVOTE, meaning other hacker are seeing it.

Also, you have to consider the private program that i have tested was NOT accepting submission, means the submit button is disabled but still i can manipulate their hacktivity.

__I would like to request you to take second look on this__, you always close my report as informative without understanding it well. If you don't understand it well, you should ask more information.

I will wait for your response.

Regards
Japz

activities.message: Thanks @japz - cool find! We're planning to add a label to the Hacktivity entry to help distinguish a published report from a normal report and we'll make sure to only show it when it was approved. Happy hacking!
